Based on my web search results, I have found significant information about literary criticism of "Brave New World" from feminist, postcolonial, and Marxist perspectives, as well as insights into how academic interpretations have evolved over time. Let me provide you with a comprehensive summary of the findings:

## Feminist Literary Criticism of "Brave New World"

Feminist critics have noted that Aldous Huxley wrote Brave New World in the 1930's, a time of misogyny and degradation towards women, which significantly influenced the novel's portrayal of female characters. While some critics say Aldous is a misogynist, others argue he was appealing to his time period so that his book would get sales.

Several key feminist critiques have emerged:

1. **Gender Roles and Power Dynamics**: Men in Brave New World seem to have more importance than women, and no female characters met in the text are of the Alpha caste. Socially, women also seem to have less power than men. However, it seems that only males choose when or when a relationship can take place.

2. **Sexual Objectification**: In Brave New World relationships are not allowed, despite this lack of relationships, women are very sexualized and suggested to be sexually active, sleeping with as many men as possible. This emphasizes the societal issue of the sexualization of women within Brave New World and how they are objectified by other characters in the story.

3. **Limited Female Agency**: Milton Birnbaum notes that in Huxley's world women "are seen chiefly in relationship to the males" and only "occupy a satellite position". Critics argue that Lenina is more heroic in her resistance to the Fordian world than the men that the novel praises and due to the rise in feminism over the last forty years it has not gone unnoticed. However due to the underlying misogyny, which Higdon states disastrously impedes characterization, themes and intentions of Brave New World, Huxley failed to do so.

## Postcolonial Literary Criticism

Postcolonial readings of "Brave New World" focus primarily on the character of John the Savage and the power dynamics between different societies:

When analyzing Brave New World from a post-colonial lens, it's easy to see that John is the oppressed, being asked to change his lifestyle and morals, and the World State is the oppressor, basically telling John that he is "so terribly queer". John is different than most people who are oppressed because not only does he fight back, he absolutely refuses to cave in to the World State's request and quite literally chooses death over living in the World State. So, despite the similarities between John's situation and the situations of oppressed entities in history, John is different because his reaction to assimilation is to fight back instead of letting the oppressors win.

If in Heart of Darkness and Darkness at Noon, Conrad and Koestler stage the empire-building phase of the will to power, whether in its colonialist or in its communist guise, in Brave New World Huxley stages its postcolonialist and postcommunist phase. Huxley's dystopian empire has now encompassed the entire planet and is called the World-State, bearing an uncanny resemblance to the New World Order envisaged by the multinational global elites of the late 20th century, after the fall of Communism.

## Marxist Literary Criticism

Marxist interpretations of "Brave New World" have been particularly rich, focusing on class struggle, economic systems, and social control:

1. **Class Structure and Social Division**: Aldous Huxley's Brave New World presents a dystopian society in which social classes are implemented to keep the society going. Huxley alludes to many of the ideas of Karl Marx throughout the novel. Marxism would be defined as the political, economic, and social principles advocated by Marx; especially: a theory and practice of socialism including the labor theory of value, dialectical materialism, the class struggle, and dictatorship of proletariat until the establishment of a classless society.

2. **Caste System Analysis**: Marxist theory applies to Brave New World in many ways including, communism, class struggle between the caste systems; Alphas, Betas, Gammas, and Epsilons, social control with soma and hypnopedia, religion being the opiate of the people, in Brave New World that is the love of servitude and Ford.

3. **Economic Control**: Although the novel touches on a number of ways in which the individual is disempowered and commodified in contemporary society, from pacifying drugs to an overreliance on technology, Huxley's critique of capitalism remains the most prominent, if only because the novel includes explicit references to the father of modern capitalist production, Henry Ford. Examining Mond's discussion of the time before the institution of the World State, Huxley's creative demonstration of capitalist reduction, and the function of the individual within capitalist society reveals the ways in which the novel seeks to highlight the dangers of unrestrained capitalist and the consumer culture is perpetuates.

## Evolution of Academic Interpretations Over Time

The critical reception and interpretation of "Brave New World" has undergone significant changes since its publication:

1. **Initial Reception**: The reception of Brave New World at its publication was primarily negative. Many were offended by the nature of Huxley's future, and very few understood the novel's philosophical implications.

2. **Later Embracement**: Upon its publication, Rebecca West praised Brave New World as "The most accomplished novel Huxley has yet written", Joseph Needham lauded it as "Mr Huxley's remarkable book", and Bertrand Russell also praised it, stating, "Mr Aldous Huxley has shown his usual masterly skill in Brave New World." Brave New World also received negative responses from other contemporary critics, although his work was later embraced.

3. **Contemporary Relevance**: Of these founding texts, Brave New World is widely acknowledged to be the one whose dystopian future most closely matches the Western world as it has actually evolved since the initial publication of the text more than eighty years ago. The essays in this volume examine the ways in which Brave New World continues to serve as an effective satirical commentary on our own reality, as well as the ways it continues to provide models for the numerous dystopian fictions that are being produced today.

4. **Evolving Critical Perspectives**: Some historical critics have interpreted the novel as a Utopian vision of Huxley. According to them, Huxley himself is a eugenicist and a strong advocate of human genetic manipulation. Therefore, because of Huxley's ambiguous position, scholars' opposing stances, and the novel's rich and ambivalent narration, some problems might arise for readers.

5. **Modern Academic Analysis**: For readers who are studying it for the first time, several essays survey the critical conversation regarding this work from all standard critical perspectives – social, gender, post-modern, psychological, and cultural as well as the more traditional historical and close readings.

The evolution of criticism shows how "Brave New World" has transformed from an initially controversial work to a cornerstone of dystopian literature that continues to generate diverse academic interpretations through feminist, postcolonial, Marxist, and other theoretical lenses, demonstrating its enduring relevance to contemporary social and political concerns.
